SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

de.exitgames.client.photon
Class PhotonPeer

Object
  PhotonPeer
Direct Known Subclasses:
LitePeer
public class PhotonPeer
extends Object

Instances of the PhotonPeer class are used to connect to a Photon server and communicate with it. A PhotonPeer instance allows communication with the Photon Server, which in turn can distribute messages to other PhotonPeer clients. An application can use more than one PhotonPeer instance, which are treated as separate users on the server. Each should have its own listener instance, to separate the operations, callbacks and events.

Author:
developer@exitgames.com

Constructor Detail

PhotonPeer

public PhotonPeer(IPhotonPeerListener listener,
                  boolean useTCP)
Creates a new PhotonPeer instance to communicate with Photon and selects either UDP or TCP as protocol. We recommend UDP.

Parameters:
listener - an IPhotonPeerListener implementation
useTCP - If false, UDP is used as underlying protocol, else TCP. Preferred\: UDP.

getPeerState

public byte getPeerState()
The PeerState is set internally and is available for debugging mostly, as all relevant state changes are also marked by callbacks to PeerStatusCallback. An application could check if the PhotonPeer instance is connected. Compare with enum PhotonPeer.PeerStateValue

getPeerID

public short getPeerID()
This peer's ID as assigned by the server or 0 if not using UDP. Will be 0xFFFF before the client connects. Used for debugging only. This value is not useful in everyday Photon usage.

getCommandBufferSize

public int getCommandBufferSize()
Size of the buffers for incoming/outgoing commands (reliable and unreliable). A bigger buffer is consuming more heap. Smaller buffers must be Dispatched more often by DispatchIncomingCommands. UDP: Incoming and outgoing commands each have separate buffers for reliable and unreliable sending. There are additional buffers for "sent commands" and "ACKs". TCP: Only two buffers exist: Incoming and outgoing commands.

setCommandBufferSize

public void setCommandBufferSize(int value)
                          throws Exception
Throws:
Exception

Sum of all commands currently queued as outgoing, including all channels and reliable, unreliable.

getChannelCount

public byte getChannelCount()
Get the number of channels available in UDP connections with Photon. Photon Channels are only supported for UDP.

public void setChannelCount(byte value)
                     throws Exception
Sets the number of channels available in UDP connections with Photon. Photon Channels are only supported for UDP.

Throws:
Exception

getWarningSize

public int getWarningSize()
The WarningSize allows the PhotonPeer class to test each individual queue for congestion (in and out, reliable and unreliable). If there are more commands than WarningSize in a queue, PhotonPeer will call the IPhotonPeerListener.peerStatusCallback(StatusCode) callback with a respective StatusCode.

setWarningSize

public void setWarningSize(int value)

getSentCountAllowance

public int getSentCountAllowance()
Number of send retries before a peer is considered lost/disconnected. Default: 5. The initial timeout countdown of a command is calculated by the current roundTripTime + 4 * roundTripTimeVariance. Please note that the timeout span until a command will be resent is not constant, but based on the roundtrip time at the initial sending, which will be doubled with every failed retry. DisconnectTimeout and SentCountAllowance are competing settings: either might trigger a disconnect on the client first, depending on the values and Rountrip Time.

setSentCountAllowance

public void setSentCountAllowance(int value)

getTimePingInterval

public int getTimePingInterval()

setTimePingInterval

public void setTimePingInterval(int value)
Sets the milliseconds without reliable command before a ping command (reliable) will be sent (Default: 500ms). The ping command is used to keep track of the connection in case the client does not send reliable commands by itself.

getDisconnectTimeout

public int getDisconnectTimeout()
Milliseconds after which a reliable UDP command triggers a timeout disconnect, unless acknowledged by server. This value currently only affects UDP connections. The actual timeout might happen later, depending on the connection. Commands that are sent while having a bad roundtrip time and variance are checked less often for re-sending! DisconnectTimeout and SentCountAllowance are competing settings: either might trigger a disconnect on the client first, depending on the values and Rountrip Time. Default: 10000 ms.

setDisconnectTimeout

public void setDisconnectTimeout(int value)

getServerTimeInMilliseconds

public int getServerTimeInMilliseconds()
Approximated Environment.TickCount value of server. Photon sends TickCount updates in every reliable package. The approximation adds RoundtripTime / 2 and uses the client-system's TickCount to calculate values in-between updates (this property is new for every tick). About Environment.TickCount: The value of this property is derived from the system timer and is stored as a 32-bit signed integer. Consequently, if the system runs continuously, TickCount will increment from zero to Int32..::.MaxValue for approximately 24.9 days, then jump to Int32..::.MinValue, which is a negative number, then increment back to zero during the next 24.9 days.

fetchServerTimestamp

public void fetchServerTimestamp()
This will fetch the server's timestamp and update the approximation for property ServerTimeInMilliseconds. on a single roundtrip which is done as fast as possible. The command used for this is immediately acknowledged by the server. This makes sure the roundtrip time is low and the timestamp + rountriptime / 2 is close to the original value. The server time approximation will NOT become more accurate by repeated calls. Accuracy currently depends

getRoundTripTime

public int getRoundTripTime()
Time until a reliable command is acknowledged by the server. This is also the approximate time, until a raised event reaches another client. This is done "low level" and only counts the network performance and server-time, excluding any internal delays.

getRoundTripTimeVariance

public int getRoundTripTimeVariance()
Changes of the roundtrip time as variance value. Gives a hint about how much the time is changing.

getServerAddress

public String getServerAddress()
The server address which was used in PhotonPeer.Connect() or null (before Connect() was called).

getTcpUsed

public boolean getTcpUsed()

setGetLocalMsTimestampProvider

public void setGetLocalMsTimestampProvider(PhotonPeer.GetLocalMsTimestampProvider value)
                                    throws Exception
This setter for a timestamp delegate replaces the internally used Environment.TickCount with any fitting function.

Throws:
Exception - if peer.GetPeerState() is not PS_DISCONNECTED.

connect

public boolean connect(String serverAddress,
                       String appID)
This method does a DNS lookup (if necessary) and connects to the given serverAddress (ip:port). When the connection is established, a callback to IPhotonPeerListener.peerStatusCallback(StatusCode) is triggered. The appID is the name of an application of Photon. By default, it is "Lite" but other samples use "LiteLobby" and "MmoDemo". Lite implements the operations OpJoin, OpRaiseEvent and OpLeave and is a useful example to build your own games on. Working with "localhost:5055" might return true but fail on receive. This is not the case when using a remote server.

Parameters:
serverAddress - Must be IP\:Port (e.g. 127.0.0.1\:5055) or Hostname\:Port (e.g. "udp.exitgames.com\:5055")
appID - Defines which application running in the Photon Server is used. Default\: null or "Lite".
Returns:
true if IP available (DNS name is resolved) and server is being connected. false on error.

disconnect

public void disconnect()
This method disconnects from the Photon Server which will end communication (if any). Disconnect is also a command on the Server. The callback is a call to with a returnCode of StatusCode.Disconnect and an operationCode of LiteOpCode.Blank. If the client is disconnected already or the connection thread is stopped, then there is no callback. Disconnecting will also leave the joined game (if any) and trigger the respective event (LiteEventCode.Leave) for the remaining players.

stopThread

public void stopThread()
This method immediately closes a connection (pure client side). If the connections was open, this will trigger a disconnect callback to PeerStatusCallback() with a returnCode of StatusCode.Disconnect and an operationCode of LiteOpCode.Blank.

service

public void service()
This method includes the PhotonPeer internal processes into the main application's loop without another Thread. Call this method regularly (2..10 times a second). It processes received commands and events and will send out your commands. This will Dispatch ANY remaining buffered commands or events AND will send queued outgoing command. Fewer calls might be more effective if a device cannot send many packets per second, as multiple operations might be combined into one package. For more control, there are also separate functions (see below) to Dispatch and send.

See Also:
dispatchIncomingCommands()

sendOutgoingCommands

public void sendOutgoingCommands()
Gather commands from all (out)queues until udp-packet is full and sends it!

dispatchIncomingCommands

public boolean dispatchIncomingCommands()
Checks the incoming queue and Dispatches received data if possible. Returns if a Dispatch happened or not, so you can Dispatch until false is returned.

opCustom

public boolean opCustom(byte customOpCode,
                        TypedHashMap<Byte,Object> customOpParameters,
                        boolean sendReliable)
Simple wrapper for OpCustom() without parameters: channelId (=0), encrypt (=false).

opCustom

public boolean opCustom(byte customOpCode,
                        TypedHashMap<Byte,Object> customOpParameters,
                        boolean sendReliable,
                        byte channelId)
Simple wrapper for OpCustom() without parameter: encrypt (=false)

opCustom

public boolean opCustom(byte customOpCode,
                        TypedHashMap<Byte,Object> customOpParameters,
                        boolean sendReliable,
                        byte channelId,
                        boolean encrypt)
Allows the client to send any operation to the Photon Server by setting any opCode and the operation's parameters. Photon can be extended with new operations which are identified by a single byte, defined server side and known as operation code (opCode). Similarly, the operation's parameters are defined server side as byte keys of values, which a client sends as customOpParameters accordingly. This is explained in more detail as "Custom Operations".

Parameters:
customOpCode - Operations are handled by their byte\-typed code. The codes of the "Lite" application are in the struct LiteOpCode.
customOpParameters - A Hashtable containing parameters as key\-value pair. The key is byte\-typed, while the value is any serializable datatype.
sendReliable - Selects if the operation must be acknowledged or not. If false, the operation is not guaranteed to reach the server.
encrypt - Encrypts the operation before its sent. To use encryption, a client must first exchange keys with the server.
channelId - The channel in which this operation should be sent.
Returns:
Consecutive invocationID of the OP. Will throw Exception if not connected or channelId >= channelCount.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if encryption is attempted but not available.

opExchangeKeysForEncryption

public short opExchangeKeysForEncryption()
